title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" includes Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers in the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the definition of an Assistant United States Attorney in the Federal Employees' Retirement System. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" appoints assistant United States attorneys under section 542 of title 28. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first applicable pay period after a 90-day period from enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. For the purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act and serving in that capacity on such date. The Department of Justice must provide notice to these individuals regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to make an election under this Act. An incumbent appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the Act's effective date can choose to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act never existed. Failure to elect on time is treated as an election under option A on the last allowable day. The election must be made before the 90th day after the deadline. An election under this subsection must be made before the 90th day after the notice is provided or the incumbent separates from service. No change in retirement coverage will occur before the election is made. The election under subsection (c)(1)(A) must be made before the 90th day after notice is provided or separation from service. Retroactive effect applies to service performed as an Assistant United States Attorney. The Act allows for retroactive treatment of service performed before the effective date of the election, in accordance with applicable provisions of chapter 83 or 84 of title 5, United States Code. The Department of Justice must make makeup contributions to the Office of Personnel Management. The Office of Personnel Management requires remittance of additional contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, which must be deposited in the Treasury of the United States. The total amount to be remitted includes individual and Government contributions for all incumbents described in subsection (d). Government contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, including interest, are required for all incumbents described in subsection (d) for service performed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of their election under subsection (c). No individual liability is created for any shortfall in contributions required. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for implementing the Act, including determining interest on contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" refers to an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
